contextId.information: Here the words "mourn with" and "comfort" share similar meanings. The friends try to comfort Job by mourning with him. AT: "to grieve with Job in order to help ease his suffering." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: to mourn with him and to comfort him

contextId.information: These two phrases both refer to Job asking God for help or pleading with God for mercy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: diligently sought God ... presented your request to the Almighty

contextId.information: "shaped and formed me." The words "framed" and "fashioned" are similar in meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

"Come to nothing" is an idiom meaning be completely destroyed. This phrase expands on the word "fall" and emphasizes complete destruction. AT: "mountains completely fall apart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: mountains fall and come to nothing

contextId.information: These two words basically mean the same thing and emphasize how wicked humans are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The words "without clothing" mean the same thing as "naked." AT: "completely naked" or "naked because they have no clothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two phrases are used together to emphasize that the darkness is extremely dark. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These phrases mean the same thing. AT: "Listen carefully to me, Job." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Pay attention, Job, and listen to me

contextId.information: The words "thick gloom" mean basically the same thing as, and intensify the word "darkness." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

The words "full of days" means basically the same thing as "being old." The two phrases form a common idiom. AT: "a very old man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: being old and full of days
